snippet.textDisplay:
I really really love your way of teaching! I have been watching you for a year or two and i am really impressed.
I am 20y.o and i study obstetrics. We have a doctor who gives us 2 classes per week, and he is our favourite one for the same reason as you would be when you become a teacher - he makes us WANT to learn more, WANT to understand. Just like you - he wants us to understand, not to memorize the facts, and that is rare (we really really love hım). I really hope you see this comment and know that you do a lot for a lot of kids and you will be an amazing teacher!
I really Look forward to these lives, keep up the good work! 😎🤓
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Hey Mark! Your form to submit an answer to next weeks question is closed. So I’ll post my answer here: I think you will gain some weight because a fart contains of some gasses, as far as I know mostly methane and this is a bit lighter then air. So by releasing a certain amount of that gas from your body it doesn’t lift you up anymore. But the effect will be within a gram or two I believe.

snippet.textDisplay: I know you probably won't see this, but I'm confused. When I sing, or speak for that matter, and I try to sing more forcefully I get louder -> higher amplitude. I would have thought that amplitude of the helium would be greater but pitch would be the same if more force was applied to it. My question is, where does amplitude come in when we are talking about increased force? Is the idea that I can't actually control the frequency of my vocal chords, only their speed in relation to the gas around them?
snippet.textOriginal: I know you probably won't see this, but I'm confused. When I sing, or speak for that matter, and I try to sing more forcefully I get louder -> higher amplitude. I would have thought that amplitude of the helium would be greater but pitch would be the same if more force was applied to it. My question is, where does amplitude come in when we are talking about increased force? Is the idea that I can't actually control the frequency of my vocal chords, only their speed in relation to the gas around them?

snippet.textDisplay: The answer to the question "does farting make you weigh more or less?" Well, I  think that the answer to that is: It makes you heavier because your farts are made of methane, which is lighter than air. So, when you have the methane in your body, you are lighter. When you fart, you are getting rid of the methane, which means when you fart, you get heavier because you get rid of the methane in your body.
snippet.textOriginal: The answer to the question "does farting make you weigh more or less?" Well, I  think that the answer to that is: It makes you heavier because your farts are made of methane, which is lighter than air. So, when you have the methane in your body, you are lighter. When you fart, you are getting rid of the methane, which means when you fart, you get heavier because you get rid of the methane in your body.

snippet.textDisplay: 99% of farts are basically just atmosphere (oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon dioxide) and releasing that does not change your weight.  BUT the remaining 1% is what gives farts force and is made of methane and sulfur compounds that are heavier than air. So farting out these compounds would make one TECHNICALLY a itty bitty bit lighter afterward. (Not an efficient weight loss strategy).
snippet.textOriginal: 99% of farts are basically just atmosphere (oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon dioxide) and releasing that does not change your weight.  BUT the remaining 1% is what gives farts force and is made of methane and sulfur compounds that are heavier than air. So farting out these compounds would make one TECHNICALLY a itty bitty bit lighter afterward. (Not an efficient weight loss strategy).

snippet.textDisplay:
if mark considers air as a fluid, and since farts are made of oxygen, nitrogen, carbon dioxide, hydrogen, and methane, which are gases, and since fluids have density/weight, this means this "if you fart, then you should gain a very, very, very small amount weight" although you have to consider how long you fart and what you ate before you fart.


Edit: in school, my class did an experiment. what happened was that we let the air out of a balloon.(we use oxygen) We measured the density of the balloon before and after we let out the air. the balloon weighed less.
snippet.textOriginal:
if mark considers air as a fluid, and since farts are made of oxygen, nitrogen, carbon dioxide, hydrogen, and methane, which are gases, and since fluids have density/weight, this means this "if you fart, then you should gain a very, very, very small amount weight" although you have to consider how long you fart and what you ate before you fart.


Edit: in school, my class did an experiment. what happened was that we let the air out of a balloon.(we use oxygen) We measured the density of the balloon before and after we let out the air. the balloon weighed less.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi!!!
Nice video, although the explanation is really good I have a question,
At some hotels with nice swimming pools, you can hear music with your head under the water, and the pitch of the music is normal, so my question is how that happens since water is a far more dense fluid than air.
I suspect the answer is that in that case the water only acts as a transmission medium, and the noise is not generated by a moutn there, but not sure.
Best regards
snippet.textOriginal:
Hi!!!
Nice video, although the explanation is really good I have a question,
At some hotels with nice swimming pools, you can hear music with your head under the water, and the pitch of the music is normal, so my question is how that happens since water is a far more dense fluid than air.
I suspect the answer is that in that case the water only acts as a transmission medium, and the noise is not generated by a moutn there, but not sure.
Best regards

snippet.textDisplay:
You could take this to gravity.

We live on Earth. Earth has a gravitational pull strength of 1G

The moon has a gravitational pull strength of 0.333G. That means we can exert a force of 3x the amount of force on Earth. For example, you can lift a 5 pound weight on Earth with relative ease but on the moon, you can lift a 15 pound weight with the same force.
snippet.textOriginal:
You could take this to gravity.

snippet.textDisplay: The answer to next video's question depends on whether fart gas is more dense than air or less dense. If it is less dense than air, then you will gain weight, while if it is more dense than air, you will lose weight. I am pretty sure that is right.

snippet.textDisplay:
About the farts, you do lose mass, but you might gain some buoyancy. However given that the gas is under pressure, I'd guess it takes less volume inside than outside, so I would guess the buoyancy gain is probably not compensating for the weight loss, even if what you're measuring is apparent weight as opposed to mass. The buoyancy gain also assumes a fart is heavier than air, which isn't obvious ; but given that it shouldn't compensate the weight loss, I think you're still losing weight in both cases.


Thanks for the videos Mark, don't be worried about the algorithm, if anything you'll make things better for the time period (possibly at the cost of some viewership when you return to normal schedule, but just like the buoyancy I doubt it will compensate for all the viewers you'll gain in the meantime!).

Also - even if gases are fluids, you can't just turn yourself upside down to let the sulfur hexafluoride out, Cody explained this in one of his videos - you need to forcefully breathe out the gas, it won't come out by itself :-)
snippet.textOriginal:
About the farts, you do lose mass, but you might gain some buoyancy. However given that the gas is under pressure, I'd guess it takes less volume inside than outside, so I would guess the buoyancy gain is probably not compensating for the weight loss, even if what you're measuring is apparent weight as opposed to mass. The buoyancy gain also assumes a fart is heavier than air, which isn't obvious ; but given that it shouldn't compensate the weight loss, I think you're still losing weight in both cases.


Thanks for the videos Mark, don't be worried about the algorithm, if anything you'll make things better for the time period (possibly at the cost of some viewership when you return to normal schedule, but just like the buoyancy I doubt it will compensate for all the viewers you'll gain in the meantime!).

Also - even if gases are fluids, you can't just turn yourself upside down to let the sulfur hexafluoride out, Cody explained this in one of his videos - you need to forcefully breathe out the gas, it won't come out by itself :-)

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm sure it was a bit of a rush for you to plan this out, but (as a pre-service 4th through 9th grade, math and science, teacher in student teaching this semester [prior to Ohio closing schools a week and a half ago]) that went well! One of the things I like about your videos is that you are able to explain most concepts in a way that even young kids could understand. Well done! I hope your work towards a teaching license goes well; your work explaining the science of things on YouTube has helped you prepare for that. Continue to lean on your friends and family for assistance in creating lessons; it really helps to have an outside, non-educator mind to bounce ideas off of and make sure things make sense lol
I will be sharing this video with my 4th graders. I hope it gets you some more views and helps them learn some pretty cool science :)
Thank you for this cool lesson! Good luck and I can't wait to see more!
snippet.textOriginal:

I will be sharing this video with my 4th graders. I hope it gets you some more views and helps them learn some pretty cool science :)
Thank you for this cool lesson! Good luck and I can't wait to see more!
